0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-obama-idUSKCN1021ZD	Obama: dark Trump vision 'doesn't really jibe' with facts	"
By Ayesha Rascoe and Roberta Rampton
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The dark vision of America under siege described by Donald Trump in his acceptance speech for the Republican presidential nomination does not mesh with reality
column2: U.S. President Barack Obama said on Friday.Obama noted that the ""birds were chirping and the sun was out"" for most Americans after Trump's Thursday night speech
column3: which expounded on the threats to America from illegal immigrants
column4: Islamic State militants
column5: and race-related violence.""This idea that America is somehow on the verge of collapse
column6: this vision of violence and chaos everywhere
column7: doesn't really jibe with the experience of most people
column8: Obama said at a White House news conference after meeting with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto.Obama said the violent crime rate in America has been lower during his 7-1/2 years in office than any time during the last three or four decades
column9: despite an ""uptick"" in murders in some cities this year
column10: and the recent high-profile killings of black men and police officers.The timing of Obama's quickly arranged short meeting with Pena Nieto presented both leaders with a convenient platform from which to criticize Trump.Just three weeks ago
column11: Obama - who has six months left in the White House - invited the Mexican president to visit one last time before the U.S. president leaves on Jan. 20.

column1: Trump has pledged to build a wall at the Mexico border to keep out illegal immigrants and drugs
column2: and to force Mexico to pay for it.The New York businessman has also promised to slap tariffs on some U.S. products made in Mexico
column3: and seek radical changes or even discard the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) between the United States
column4: Mexico and Canada.Pena Nieto was first to mention Trump
column5: but said he respected both Trump and presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton
column6: and would work with constructively and in good faith with whoever wins the Nov. 8 election.In March
column7: Pena Nieto likened Trump's ""strident tone"" to the ascent of dictators Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini. But he said on Friday that he had never pointed the finger at any of the candidates
column8: saying that anything he had said had been taken out of context.

column1: And he stressed that the two nations' futures were closely bound.""The closeness between the United States and Mexico is more than a relationship between governments. It's a solid and unbreakable relationship between millions of people who live in both nations
column2: Pena Nieto said.Obama said the rate of illegal immigration is down from past decades
column3: and praised Mexico for helping to address a flood of migrants fleeing Central America and for work on drug trafficking.

column1: A Mexico that has a healthy economy
column2: a Mexico that can help us build stability and security in Central America
column3: that's going to do a lot more to solve any migration crisis or drug trafficking problem than a wall
column4: Obama said.Obama and Pena Nieto praised the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal as addressing some of the criticisms of NAFTA. Both Trump and Clinton have said they oppose the TPP
column5: which has yet to be ratified by the U.S. Congress.""There are going to be different visions about where we should go as a country
column6: Obama said
column7: running down a list of economic issues facing the nation.""But we're not going to make good decisions based on fears that don't have a basis in fact
column8: he said. (Additional reporting by Doina Chiacu
column9: David Alexander and Eric Walsh in Washington
column12: Adriana Barrera and Michael O'Boyle in Mexico City; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-davidduke-idUSKCN1021WA	Former Ku Klux Klan leader Duke runs for U.S. Senate in Louisiana	"
By Bryn Stole
| BATON ROUGE
column2: La.

column1: BATON ROUGE
column2: La. David Duke
column3: a former leader of the white supremacist Ku Klux Klan
column4: launched his candidacy on Friday for the U.S. Senate from Louisiana
column5: saying white people are threatened in America and that he hears echoes of his views in Donald Trump's rhetoric.Duke
column6: a Republican
column7: is a former Louisiana state legislator and unsuccessful candidate for governor who served a 15-month federal prison sentence after pleading guilty in 2002 to felony charges of tax evasion and mail fraud.Trump
column8: the Republican presidential nominee
column9: drew criticism in February for failing to quickly disavow support from Duke.At a news conference in Baton Rouge after officially filing as a candidate to succeed outgoing Republican Senator David Vitter
column12: said he watched Trump's speech accepting the Republican presidential nomination on Thursday in Cleveland and heard echoes of his own past political platforms.""I don't really care what Donald Trump says about me. I respect what he's doing
column13: Duke said.In an online video announcing his candidacy
column15: ""I'm overjoyed to see Donald Trump and most Americans embrace most of the issues that I've championed for years.""In his video
column16: Duke said he believes in equal rights and respect for all Americans but ""what makes me different is I also demand respect for the rights and heritage of European-Americans.""Duke's announcement came as Louisiana's capital grapples with racial tensions after the fatal July 5 shooting by police of a black man named Alton Sterling and the July 17 shooting deaths of three police officers by a black U.S. Marine Corps veteran.

column1: In his comments to reporters
column2: Duke called the Black Lives Matter protest movement that arose after a series of killings of black men by police in various U.S. cities a ""terrorist group.""Duke said that ""European-Americans"" need a politician to fight for their interests and that white people are threatened in the United States. Duke
column3: the former Grand Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan
column4: said he was no longer affiliated with the group.'HATE-FILLED FRAUD'

column1: Duke's announcement drew and swift and scathing condemnation from Republican leaders and others. The Republican Party of Louisiana called Duke a ""felon and hate-filled fraud"" who does not embody Republican values.Ward Baker
column2: executive director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee
column3: which supports Republican candidates in Senate races
column4: said Duke will never get the organization's backing.Louisiana does not hold party primaries. Instead
column5: candidates from all parties are placed on the same ballot. If no one wins a simple majority in the Nov. 8 election
column6: the top two vote-getters enter a runoff.Duke used this system to his advantage when he ran for governor in 1991 and made it to a runoff against former Governor Edwin Edwards
column7: who had left office under a cloud of controversy for misconduct in office.

column1: Other candidates seeking to replace Vitter in the Senate include Republican U.S. congressmen Charles Boustany and John Fleming. Vitter did not seek re-election to the Senate after a prostitution scandal helped derail his bid to become Louisiana governor.""I strongly denounce the racism
column2: bigotry and anti-Semitism of David Duke. His views are a relic of ancient history and are repugnant to Louisianians
column3: Boustany said. A spokesman for Fleming said the congressman ""is wholly focused on uniting Louisiana voters of all races
column4: creeds and religions."" In February
column5: Trump initially blamed his failure to reject Duke's support on not having heard an interviewer clearly. ""I disavowed David Duke all weekend long
column6: on Facebook
column7: on Twitter
column8: and obviously
column10: Trump told NBC's ""Today"" show after being widely criticized. (Additional reporting by Gina Cherelus in New York
column11: Susan Cornwell in Washington and Ginger Gibson in Cleveland; Editing by Daniel Wallis and Will Dunham)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN10114A	Trump accepts Republican nomination
column2: vows to put 'America first'	"

column1: By Steve Holland
| CLEVELAND
CLEVELAND Donald Trump accused Democratic rival Hillary Clinton of a legacy of ""death
column2: destruction
column3: terrorism and weakness"" as U.S. secretary of state and vowed to be tough on crime and illegal immigrants in a speech on Thursday accepting the Republican presidential nomination.Trump's 75-minute speech was designed to set the tone for the general election campaign against Clinton
column4: an answer to Republicans who say the best way he can unify the divided party is to detail why the Democrat should not be elected on Nov. 8.As the crowd chanted: ""Lock her up"" for her handling of U.S. foreign policy
column5: Trump waved them off and said: ""Let's defeat her in November."" Thousands of supporters who were gathered in the convention hall roared their approval. When it was over
column6: Trump was joined on stage by family members as balloons cascaded from above and confetti blew around the arena.A CNN snap poll of viewers of the speech said 57 percent had a ""very positive reaction"" to the address and 18 percent a somewhat positive reaction
column7: while 24 percent said it had a negative effect.Social media sentiment toward Trump based on tweets that mentioned his name was slightly more negative than positive shortly after his speech. The acceptance speech by Trump
column9: closed out a four-day convention that underscored his struggle to heal fissures in the Republican Party over his anti-illegal-immigrant rhetoric and concerns about his temperament. The event was boycotted by many big-name establishment Republicans
column10: such as 2012 nominee Mitt Romney and members of the Bush family that gave the party its last two presidents.Trump presented a bleak view of America under siege from illegal immigrants
column12: hindered by crumbling infrastructure and weakened by unfair trade deals and race-related violence.Accusing illegal immigrants of taking jobs from American citizens and committing crimes
column13: Trump vowed to build a ""great border wall"" against the border-crossers.""We will stop it
column14: Trump said.Trump took positions in conflict with traditional Republican policies. He said he would avoid multinational trade deals but instead pursue agreements with individual countries. He would renegotiate the NAFTA trade accord linking the United States
column15: Canada and Mexico. He would penalize companies that outsource jobs and then export their foreign-made products back into the United States.""We will never sign bad trade deals
column16: Trump thundered. ""America first!""The New York businessman
column17: who has never held elected office
column18: filled his speech with some of the bravado he used to win the Republican nomination over 16 rivals
column19: punctuating his rhetorical points by waving an index finger.

column1: I have joined the political arena so that the powerful can no longer beat up on people that cannot defend themselves
column2: Trump said. ""Nobody knows the system better than me
column3: which is why I alone can fix it.""In his speech
column4: Trump portrayed himself as a fresh alternative to traditional politicians
column5: willing to consider new approaches to vexing problems and help working-class people who may feel abandoned.Laying out his case against Clinton
column6: he denounced nation-building policies that were actually put in place to some extent by George W. Bush
column7: without mentioning by name the Republican president who launched wars in Afghanistan and Iraq.Trump said policies pursued by Clinton in Iraq
column8: Libya
column9: Egypt and Syria had made a bad situation worse. He blamed her for the rise of Islamic State militants and blasted her willingness to accept thousands of Syrian refugees.""After 15 years of wars in the Middle East
column10: after trillions of dollars spent and thousands of lives lost
column11: the situation is worse than it has ever been before. This is the legacy of Hillary Clinton: death
column14: Trump said.Clinton senior adviser John Podesta dismissed the speech as painting ""a dark picture of an America in decline"" and called it a reminder that Trump ""is temperamentally unfit and totally unqualified to be president of the United States.""John Weaver
column15: a senior adviser to Ohio Republican Governor John Kasich
column16: a former presidential rival to Trump
column17: said in a tweet that Trump had delivered the ""saddest
column19: most depressing acceptance speech in modern history.""

column1: 'THINGS HAVE TO CHANGE'
Trump needed a strong performance on Thursday night to improve his chances of getting a boost in opinion polls as Democrats prepare for their own
column2: more scripted convention next week in Philadelphia.In a contest that pits two politicians viewed as unfavorable by large segments of the American people
column3: Trump also accused Clinton
column5: of being the puppet of big business
column6: elite media and major donors who want to preserve the current political system.""That is why Hillary Clinton's message is that things will never change. My message is that things have to change - and they have to change right now
column7: Trump said.Trump said he would speedily address the violence that has dominated headlines
column8: such as the shooting deaths of five Dallas police officers earlier this month. He vowed to defeat ""the barbarians of ISIS
column9: the acronym for Islamic State.""I have a message for all of you: The crime and violence that today afflicts our nation will soon come to an end. Beginning on Jan. 20
column12: Trump said. The next president takes office on Jan. 20.

column1: CONVENTION DISCORD
The prevailing narrative at the Cleveland convention has not been about Trump's positions
column2: but dominated instead by the failure of he party's various factions to unite behind Trump.A series of distractions at the convention largely thwarted a bid by the Trump campaign to show him as a caring father and magnanimous business leader who would bring greater prosperity and safety to the United States. But in the end
column3: many of these points were made when Ivanka Trump
column4: Trump's daughter
column5: introduced her father.""I have seen him fight for his family. I have seen him fight for his employees. I have seen him fight for his company and now I am seeing him fight for our country
column6: she said.Trump's text of his speech
column7: released by his campaign
column8: included extensive footnotes to show where the material originated.That was perhaps in reaction to the speech given on Monday night by Trump's wife Melania
column9: who was accused of plagiarism when she repeated lines from a 2008 speech by Michelle Obama
column10: Obama's wife.A staff writer for the Trump Organization later took responsibility for the misstep. (Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson
column12: Michelle Conlin and David Alexander; Writing by Steve Holland; Editing by Howard Goller and Peter Cooney)"

4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-mexico-trade-idUSKCN1021ZZ	Obama says U.S. cannot wall itself off from economic globalization	"

WASHINGTON President Barack Obama said on Friday that globalization is a fact that ""we're not going to be able to build a wall around"" but that it was important to work to shape the process so that it benefits not just big companies but small firms as well.The U.S. leader
column2: speaking at a news conference with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto
column3: said the Trans Pacific Partnership trade deal currently being worked on has taken into account some of the weaknesses and criticisms of the North American Free Trade Agreement and sought to address those.

column1: (Reporting by Ayesha Rascoe; Writing by David Alexander; Editing by Eric Walsh)"
5	http://reuters.com/article/us-mexico-united-states-idUSKCN1021ZS	Mexican leader says respects U.S. presidential candidates	"

MEXICO CITY Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto said on Friday he respects both of the leading candidates to be the next president of the United States and will seek a ""frank and open"" dialogue with the eventual winner.Pena Nieto make the comments at a joint appearance with U.S. President Barack Obama at the White House in Washington.
(Reporting by Mexico City newsroom)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-democrats-hispanics-idUSKCN10211W	Undocumented immigrants given roles at Democratic convention	"
By Luciana Lopez
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK The Democratic Party has selected a handful of undocumented immigrants for official roles at next week's Democratic National Convention
column2: in a bid to highlight the gaping policy divide on immigration between White House hopeful Hillary Clinton and Republican rival Donald Trump.Clinton is hoping to drive Latino voters to the polls on Nov. 8 to shore up her chances against Trump
column3: who has campaigned on a promise to crack down on illegal immigration by building a wall along the Mexican border and deporting millions of undocumented foreigners if elected.""Our nation is a nation of immigrants that believes in being inclusive
column4: and that's exactly what we will continue to work toward
column5: said Leah Daughtry
column6: the chief executive officer of the committee organizing the July 25-28 convention in Philadelphia.""The voices of our nation's brave undocumented youth will be heard loud and clear
column7: Daughtry added.The picks include two members of the convention credentials and platform committees
column8: as well as several speakers. The positions are unpaid
column10: which has argued that unchecked immigration hurts American workers and undermines national security

column1: Apparently speaking at Hillary Clinton's convention is just one more job Hillary Clinton thinks Americans won't do
column2: a Trump campaign aide said in an emailed statement. ""She should have instead invited unemployed Americans
column3: or victims of crime
column4: or law enforcement."" The selections are legal because of a ""deferred action program"" adopted by President Barack Obama's administration
column5: which postpones deportations and provides work authorization for some immigrants brought to the United States as children. The Supreme Court blocked efforts to expand those protections last month.The nominations mark the first time a major U.S. political party's convention has featured so many undocumented workers among its ranks. While there was an undocumented speaker at the 2012 Democratic convention
column6: the party has not previously tracked the immigration status of its committee members.

column1: It changes the whole conversation when you have someone directly affected at the table
column2: said Cesar Vargas
column3: a Mexican immigrant chosen for the party's policy platform committee. Hareth Andrade
column5: an undocumented immigrant from Bolivia who was approved under a deferred action program
column6: was picked for the credentials committee. The convention will also feature at least two undocumented immigrant speakers
column7: Astrid Silva and Francisca Ortiz.Clinton already has overwhelming support from minorities. Some 70 percent back her
column8: compared with 9 percent for Trump
column10: suggesting that she could have a strong chance in states like Florida
column11: Nevada and Colorado that swing between voting Democratic and Republican in presidential elections.

column1: However
column2: voter turnout among Latinos has traditionally been low
column3: hitting only about 40 percent in 2012
column4: meaning her challenge is to get more of them to cast ballots this year.Luis Fraga
column5: co-director of the Institute for Latino Studies at the University of Notre Dame
column6: said showing a commitment to progressive reform of U.S. immigration policy could help Clinton do that. He called immigration a gateway issue for minority voters that can help engage them. That's especially so because even Latinos born in the United States are often not far removed from family members who are immigrants themselves. ""Although it's not their individual experience
column7: it is their family's experience
column8: Fraga said. (Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Jonathan Oatis)"

By Amy Tennery and Angela Moon
| CLEVELAND/NEW YORK
CLEVELAND/NEW YORK At times

column3: who then officially accepted the Republican Party's presidential nomination. Since Trump announced his intention to run for the White House last year
column4: she has been steadily drawn into her father's presidential campaign along with her 35-year-old husband Jared Kushner.The couple both take part in the Trump campaign's ""family meeting"" each Monday morning
column5: helping make decisions about spending and strategy
column6: according to a source familiar with the meetings.Among the children
column7: Ivanka is the one who is often the bridge to women voters and seems to have the mission of selling her father's softer side. When she is not involved in the campaign
column8: she helps to run the family's sprawling business empire from its New York City headquarters.

column1: This week in Cleveland she has been everywhere
column2: lobbying for her father with delegates and donors
column3: appearing in television interviews and leaving a trail of picture-taking fans in her wake. One man

column5: carried a placard all week around the convention that read: ""Ivanka
column6: 2024. First Female President.""Her star turn in Cleveland was one of the top trending topics on Twitter late on Thursday
column7: with about 121 tweets mentioning her name posted every minute. Overall sentiment on her was more positive than negative by a ratio of 3 to 1
column8: according to analytics firm Zoomph.Ivanka missed her one chance to date to vote for her father: she had not changed her party registration from Democrat to Republican in time to cast a ballot in the April 19 New York primary election.She more than compensated on Thursday night
column9: some convention delegates said.""She gave us enormous insight into him and the kind of man he is
column11: a 78-year-old New Mexico delegate. ""She's (an) enormously capable young lady
column12: as is her brother. We're going to see the beginning of a dynasty here."" (Additional reporting by Michelle Conlin and Emily Flitter; Writing by Richard Valdmanis; Editing by Howard Goller)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-policy-idUSKCN10209T	To wonks hungry for policy details
column2: Trump team serves lighter fare	"

column1: By Emily Stephenson and Steve Holland
| CLEVELAND

CLEVELAND People seeking a deeper understanding of Donald Trump's economic policy came up empty-handed this week at the Republican National Convention.Best known to Americans previously as a reality TV host and having never held public office
column2: the New York businessman on Thursday accepted the party's nomination for the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential election.The party establishment has fretted over some of his plans to curb illegal immigration
column3: renegotiate trade deals and levy tariffs on China. Trump's skepticism about free trade puts him at odds with Republican orthodoxy. Wall Street investors are wary and confused.In speeches from the main stage and in panel discussions on the sidelines
column4: the four-day convention was notable for a paucity of policy details
column5: the result perhaps of a desire to play down differences among the party faithful.The lack of specifics was too much for one head of a multinational corporation
column6: who complained at a business forum that he had no idea what to expect from Trump

column11: obviously details matter.""Trump offered little insight himself in his convention-ending acceptance speech. He spoke in broad

column16: Trump said.HILLARY CLINTON THE TOP TOPIC

column3: than on what Trump has called the failed economic policies of President Barack Obama.

column13: that he said was light on details.""'Isn't Mr. Trump bad on trade?'"" he said someone would ask.

column1: 'Yes
column2: but we're going to fix it. Don't worry.'""'Isn't his tax plan a problem that's going to lose $12 trillion?' ""'Yes
column3: but we'll fix it. Don't worry.'""Kudlow and Moore also appeared on Tuesday at an event hosted by conservative advocacy group FreedomWorks

column6: which owns fast-food restaurants Hardee's and Carl's Jr.The group discussed trade and immigration policy

column8: Puzder said at one point

column1: UNCONVENTIONAL CONVENTION

Republicans typically use their nominating conventions to emphasize their candidates' main policy points. Think tanks and lobby groups hold panel discussions. Experts circulate white papers. With Trump
column2: the events were built more around his personality and the need for the party to unite behind him.    There were some such gatherings in Cleveland
column3: but fewer than usual
column4: Holtz-Eakin said.Some advisers to past Republican candidates suspected Trump was not relying on a vast team of policy advisers. Lanhee Chen
column5: an adviser to 2012 Republican nominee Mitt Romney
column6: sorted through convention speeches in 2012 before speakers delivered them because
column7: he said
column8: he wanted to make sure they hewed closely to Romney's positions.""I imagine the Trump campaign doesn't have that process in place because they don't have a lot of policy to talk about
column9: Chen said. ""It just says that policy hasn't been a priority for them. You end up with a situation where the candidate is making pronouncements that don't seem particularly well informed.""Some delegates who spoke to Reuters seemed unconcerned by the policy-light approach to the convention
column10: arguing that it was more important for the gathering to whip up enthusiasm among the delegates and forge unity.""This is more of a party
column12: a 53-year-old lawyer and delegate from Virginia. ""You don't like people talking shop at a cocktail party
column13: do you?"" (Additional reporting by James Oliphant; Writing by Howard Goller; Editing by Ross Colvin)"
